questions.text: A 45-year-old woman was referred by a dentist after she was found to have loss of lamina dura in the tooth. Her radiograph is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The X-ray of the skull shows multiple radiolucent lytic lesions with a salt and pepper appearance/pepperpot appearance. The clinical scenario and X-ray features are suggestive of hyperparathyroidism.

Radiological features of hyperparathyroidism:

  • Sub-periosteal cortical resorption of middle phalanges
    • Pathognomonic feature 
    • Seen especially in the second and third fingers
    • Also visualized in the lateral end of the clavicle and symphysis pubis
  • Loss of lamina dura 
    • Thin cortical bone of tooth socket surrounding teeth
    • Seen as a thin white line
  • Brown’s tumor
    • Expansile lytic lesion generally affecting maxilla/mandible
  • Salt and pepper appearance of the skull
  • Generalized osteopenia, thinning of cortices, and indistinct bony trabeculae

A radiograph showing subperiosteal cortical resorption is given below.

Related Pearl: Causes of lytic lesions in the skull

  • Eosinophilic granuloma (geographic lytic lesions in the vault of skull with beveled edges)
  • Multiple myeloma (punched out lytic lesion)
  • Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (permeative lesions)
  • Hyperparathyroidism (salt and pepper skull)
  • Metastasis
  • Lymphoma
  • Tuberculosis 
  • Osteomyelitis 
  • Radiation 

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs of Hyperparathyroidism

Rugger jersey spine: It refers to the prominent hyperdensities at the endplates of successive vertebrae, which mimics the striped appearance of a rugby jersey.

Subperiosteal bone resorption: This is seen on the radial side of the proximal and middle phalanges of the index and middle fingers. It is the most consistent and specific finding of hyperparathyroidism and is virtually pathognomonic of the condition.

Brown tumors / Osteitis fribrosa cystica / Von Recklinghausen's disease of bone: These are composed of pseudotumors that are made up of macrophages, blood, and connective tissue. They are seen as radiolytic areas due to the reduction in the bone trabeculae.                        

Salt and pepper appearance of the skull:  Refers to multiple tiny well-defined lucencies in the calvaria of the skull ( top part of the skull) due to resorption of the trabecular bone. Alternate areas of mineralization (salt-white) and decalcification (pepper-black)

Acral osteolysis: This is also known as the tufting of phalanges

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy is being evaluated for seizures. There is no history of weakness of any part of the body. A CT scan was done, and the image is given below. The characteristic sign depicted in the image is ______.

(MCA- middle cerebral artery)
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the CT image showing the bracket sign is suggestive of pericallosal lipoma. 

The most common site of lipoma in the brain is pericallosal region. Calcification at the periphery of the midline lipoma produces the characteristic bracket sign. Approximately 50% of patients present with seizures. Many cases are detected incidentally in utero by antenatal sonography.

Pericallosal lipomas can be grouped into two distinct types based on imaging:

  • Tubulonodular
  • Curvilinear

The tubulonodular variety is usually associated with more severe and extensive abnormalities and patients are symptomatic.

Other options:

Option B: The racing car sign refers to widely spaced lateral ventricles due to agenesis of the corpus callosum with intervening Probst bundles.

Option C: Hyperdense MCA sign- It refers to the hyperdense middle cerebral artery seen on non-enhanced CT images in acute stroke.

Option D: Dural tail sign: It refers to a linear, contrast-enhancing tail-like extension from the tumor, along the dura matter. It is most commonly seen in meningioma (present in about 60% of the cases).

questions.text: A patient with a road traffic accident(RTA) is sent to you for USG thorax suspecting a pneumothorax. You observe the following findings on USG. What mode of ultrasound did you use and what would be your advice to the accompanying doctor?

choices.text: M mode, nothing to be done
M mode, insert a chest tube at the earliest
B mode, insert a chest tube at the earliest

questions.solution:
The following image is a M-mode ultrasound showing seashore sign which suggests a normal lung and hence nothing needs to be done.

M-mode refers to motion mode. It gives the information about the motion of various structures over time in a small cross section.

On M-mode, classical signs for the grayscale imaging are seen:
• Seashore sign: normal lung
• Barcode/stratosphere sign: pneumothorax

The M-mode image in the pneumothorax demonstrates a linear, laminar pattern in the tissue superficial to the pleural line and a similar linear pattern deep to the pleural line. This phenomenon, known as the stratosphere sign or barcode sign, indicates absent lung sliding and suggests the presence of pneumothorax.

The M-mode image of a normal lung demonstrates a linear, laminar pattern in the tissue superficial to the pleural line and a granular or sandy appearance deep to the pleural line. This phenomenon is known as the seashore sign, and it indicates normal lung sliding and excludes pneumothorax at this interspace.

B mode USG refers to brightness mode. It shows two-dimensional images.

questions.text: The spinal X-ray of an elderly man with diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis (DISH) will have all of the following features, except:

choices.text: Anterolateral ossification of at least four contiguous vertebrae

questions.solution:
The spinal X-ray in diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis (DISH) /Forestier's disease shows relative preservation of disc height.

Forestier’s disease is a common condition seen in the late-middle-aged/ elderly characterized by hyperostosis seen at multiple sites, but mainly in the spine at enthesis sites (where tendons and ligaments attach to the bone). The most common site for spinal involvement is between T7 to T12. Cervical and lumbar hyperostosis may also be seen.

DISH is not confined to the spine and may also be seen elsewhere in the skeleton - at attachments of ligaments to the bone around the pelvis, the calcaneus and other tarsals, elbow, hands, and patella.

DISH is fundamentally a radiological diagnosis and the symptoms are usually mild compared to the radiographic change.

Features of DISH include:

  • Ossification along the anterolateral aspect of at least four contiguous vertebrae
  • Relative preservation of disc height and absence of other features of osteoarthritis; and
  • Absence of sacroiliac joint erosion, fusion, and facet joint ankylosis
  • Hyperostosis along the anterolateral aspect of the vertebral bodies with bridging across the disc spaces
  • Calcification of anterior and sometimes posterior longitudinal ligaments appearing as 'flowing' or dripping like candle wax.

The spinal hyperostosis of DISH tends to be more irregular with a wavy surface contour than that seen in spondyloarthritis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the emergency room with complaints of new-onset left-sided chest pain. He had a recent history of a viral infection. ECG showed diffuse ST elevation with upward concavity and echocardiography detected a pericardial effusion. What is the finding that can be seen on the chest radiograph of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of pericardial effusion as a result of acute pericarditis. The chest radiograph may show a water-bottle configuration due to enlargement of the cardiac silhouette because of the pericardial effusion.

Pericardial effusion is usually associated with chest pain and/or the ECG changes of pericarditis (widespread ST elevation, often with upward concavity). If the effusion is large, the ECG may show electrical alternans. Heart sounds may be faint, friction rub, and the apical impulse may not be audible.

Echocardiography is a widely used imaging technique that allows localization and estimation of the quantity of pericardial fluid.

The chest X-ray shows an enlargement of the cardiac silhouette- water-bottle configuration. It may be normal in small effusions. The lateral radiograph may show the oreo cookie sign. It is a vertical opaque line (pericardial fluid) separating a vertical lucent line (paracardial fat) directly behind the sternum anteriorly from a similar lucent vertical line (epicardial fat) posteriorly. 

CT and MRI are indicated when echocardiography is inconclusive, when the effusion is loculated or hemorrhagic or if there is pericardial thickening.

A water bottle configuration on a chest X-ray is shown below.

Other options:

Option B: A boot-shaped heart is seen in patients with Tetrology of Fallot. It refers to the appearance of an upturned cardiac apex due to right ventricular hypertrophy. 

Option C: Batwing appearance is seen in pulmonary edema. It refers to the appearance of perihilar consolidation.

Option D: The figure 3 sign is seen in the aortic coarctation. It is formed by pre-stenotic dilatation of the aortic arch and indentation of the left subclavian artery at the coarctation site and post-stenotic dilatation of the descending aorta.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman with history of squamous cell carcinoma lung presents with shortness of breath. Her chest X-ray is shown below. Which among the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows the golden S sign which is seen in the right upper lobe collapse.

Golden S-sign is seen on both PA chest radiographs and on CT scans in the right upper lobe collapse. It is named because this sign resembles a reverse S shape, and is therefore sometimes referred to as the reverse S-sign of Golden. 

Although typically seen with the right upper lobe collapse, the S-sign can also be seen with the collapse of other lobes. It is created by a central mass obstructing the upper lobe bronchus. It should raise suspicion of a primary bronchogenic carcinoma. It can also be caused by other central masses, such as metastasis, primary mediastinal tumor, or enlarged lymph nodes.

The additional finding in this X-ray is the presence of calcified breast implants.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented to the outpatient department with dysphagia. Barium swallow was done and it showed the following finding in the lower end of the esophagus. The most probable cause is
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis, in this case, is Schatzki’s ring.

Schatzki’s ring is a thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction. It is often associated with hiatal hernia. The patient experiences brief episodes of dysphagia during hurried ingestion of solid foods.

The presence of a ring in the esophagus, with or without hiatal hernia, can be visualized on barium swallow.

Treatment:

For symptomatic patients who do not have reflux, the best form of treatment consists of esophageal dilation for relief of the obstructive symptoms. In patients who have proven reflux and a mechanically defective sphincter, an antireflux procedure is done to obtain relief and avoid repeated dilation.

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

questions.text: A young woman came to the gynecologist with complaints of inability to conceive even after regular intercourse. Semen analysis of her partner was unremarkable. Hysterosalpingography revealed the following finding. Which of the following is incorrect about the condition?

choices.text: Functional rudimentary horn can present with hematometra
It occurs due to the failure of normal development of one Mullerian duct
MRI shows banana-like configuration of the uterine cavity
It is a class IV uterine malformation

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of unicornuate uterus and it is not a class IV uterine malformation, but a class II Mullerian malformation according to the American Fertility Society. Class IV uterine malformation refers to a bicornuate uterus.

The history of infertility and hysterosalpingography(HSG) showing a spindle-shaped or banana-shaped uterine cavity deviated to the left with a patent left fallopian tube suggests a unicornuate uterus. It results from the failure of the normal development of one müllerian duct.  It is associated with increased spontaneous abortion, obstetric complications, and renal abnormalities.

On T2-weighted MR images, the unicornuate uterus demonstrates a curved, elongated uterus with tapering of the fundal segment off the midline. This is known as the banana-like configuration. Normal uterine zonal anatomy is maintained.

If a functional rudimentary horn is present, it usually demonstrates lower signal intensity and might contain endometrial tissue. They have increased chances of endometriosis and hematometra which can be an indication for excision.

questions.solution:

questions.text: A 1-year-old boy presents with shortness of breath and bluish discoloration of lips. Chest X-ray shows a boot-shaped heart due to an upturned cardiac apex. The finding seen on the chest X-ray is due to:
questions.solution:
The clinical description of shortness of breath and bluish discoloration of lips, along with boot-shaped heart on chest X-ray, suggests tetralogy of Fallot (TOF). The findings of a boot-shaped heart due to the upturned cardiac apex is due to right ventricular hypertrophy.

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is a cyanotic congenital heart condition. The four cardinal features of the tetralogy of Fallot are as follows:

  • Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • Obstruction of the right ventricular outflow tract (subpulmonary stenosis)
  • An aorta that overrides the ventricular septum
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy

The image given below shows cardinal features seen in TOF:

 

Children with TOF usually present with dyspnea on exertion, they characteristically assume a squatting position for relief of dyspnea. During anoxic spells, children start crying, become dyspneic and cyanotic, and may eventually lose consciousness. 

A chest x-ray of a child with TOF typically shows a boot-shaped heart due to the upturned cardiac apex. This is mainly because of right ventricular hypertrophy. Other chest x-ray features in tetralogy of Fallot are:

  • Pulmonary oligaemia (due to pulmonary stenosis)
  • Normal size heart (heart failure is not a feature in TOF)
  • Right-sided aortic arch (25%)

Medical management with oral propranolol prevents cyanotic spells, surgical correction is the definitive treatment of choice. The intravenous administration of prostaglandin E1 can be tried to keep ductus arteriosus open while awaiting surgery.

questions.text: A post–myocardial infarction patient presented to the emergency room with sudden-onset breathlessness and cough with frothy sputum. The patient's chest x-ray, on PA view, revealed the following findings. Identify the lines.
questions.solution:
The above clinical features are suggestive of pulmonary edema due to left-sided heart failure, and Kerley B lines are characteristic findings seen in this setting. Kerley B lines are horizontal subpleural lines, 1 cm in length and 1–3 mm in thickness, usually seen in the middle or lower zone of the lungs. 

Radiological signs of left-sided heart failure:

  • Cardiomegaly - Enlargement of the cardiac silhouette
  • Kerley B lines - Horizontal lines in the periphery of the lower posterior lung fields
  • Upper lobe pulmonary venous congestion 
  • Interstitial edema

 Types of Kerley lines:  

  • Kerley A lines:
    • They are deep septal lines and are longer than Kerley B lines.
    • They radiate from the periphery to the central portion of the lungs.
    • HRCT is the best modality for the demonstration of Kerley A lines.
    • They indicate severe pulmonary edema.
  • Kerley B lines:
    • These are thin lines 1–2 cm in length in the periphery of the lung.
    • They are perpendicular to the pleural surface and extend out to it.
    • They represent thickened subpleural interlobular septa.
    • They are usually seen at the lung bases.
  • Kerley C lines :
    • They occur due to the thickening of the lung parenchymal interstitium.
    • They have a reticular pattern on chest radiography.
  • Kerley D lines 
    •  They are exactly the same as Kerley B lines, except that they are seen on lateral chest radiographs, in the retrosternal air gap.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presented with pain and stiffness in her hands for 1 year. The joints involved were the proximal and distal interphalangeal joints. The wrist and metacarpophalangeal joints were spared. Her X-ray is shown below. The given finding is classically seen in _________

The given image shows a gull-wing appearance/ seagull erosions/ saw-tooth appearance, which is classically seen in erosive osteoarthritis (OA) of the hand.

In OA of the hand, the joints involved are the distal and proximal interphalangeal joints (DIP, PIP), and the first carpometacarpal joint (base of the thumb), while the wrist, elbow, and ankle are usually spared.

The nodules palpable in the DIP are called Heberden’s nodes, while those palpable in the PIP are called Bouchard’s nodes.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked "A" in the CT scan of the thorax shown below.
questions.solution:
The structure marked "A" in the CT Thorax is the ascending aorta.

In a CT study, X-rays are applied in a circular motion and body tissue slices are recreated mathematically. Different tissues are seen with different intensities, depending on the proportion of attenuation of the X-rays that pass through them.

  • Air and water are displayed as low-intensity (dark appearance) areas because they produce only little attenuation.
  • Bone is displayed as a high-intensity structure (bright appearance) because of its significant attenuation.
  • High density is seen in the presence of hyperemia, freshly clotted blood, and contrast agents.
  • Edema and necrosis are seen as low-intensity areas.

questions.text: The image below is an axial CT scan of the upper abdomen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image is suggestive of pseudomyxoma peritonei

Pseudomyxoma peritonei is a peritoneal neoplasia characterized by the accumulation of mucin-producing tumor cells in the peritoneal cavity and usually occurs following rupture of mucinous adenocarcinoma of the appendix. However, it may also occur due to the rupture of the tumors of ovary, pancreas, stomach, colorectal, or urachus.

Imaging findings:

  • Accumulation of mucinous material, which is seen as masses of low attenuation on CT and moderately high signal intensity on MRI.
  • Scalloped indentation of the visceral surfaces of the liver and spleen.
  • The peritoneal surfaces may be thickened due to the solid components of the tumor.

questions.text: The USG of the gall bladder of a forty-year-old obese female patient appears as below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The ultrasonography of the gallbladder shows acoustic shadow, indicating the presence of stone in the gallbladder (cholelithiasis).

Cholelithiasis is commonly seen in women. Over 70% of the gallstones are composed of cholesterol, while the pigment gallstones composed of calcium carbonate constitute most of the remaining 30%.

Radiological features:

X-ray: Only calcified stones are visible.

Ultrasonography:

  • The gallstones appear as echogenic foci, which cast acoustic shadow. Stone mobility may be demonstrated, if it is not impacted.
  • In contrast, a gallbladder polyp is fixed, and does not cast any acoustic shadow.
  • In gallbladder full of stones, there is a dense acoustic shadowing with the presence of two parallel curved echogenic lines separated by a thin anechoic space. This characteristic appearance is referred to as ‘Double-arc shadow sign’, or wall-echo-shadow sign.

The image-below shows wall-echo-shadow sign due to the presence of a large gall stone.

Option A: Porcelain gallbladder refers to calcification of the gallbladder wall. The image below shows calcification in the gall bladder wall(on CT) suggestive of a porcelain gall bladder.

questions.text: A newborn baby was brought to the NICU because he was lethargic and unable to take feeds. A bruit is heard over the anterior fontanelle.  The baby was admitted and further investigations revealed high output cardiac failure. The baby’s MR angiography is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and MR angiograph point to a diagnosis of Vein of Galen malformation. The MR angiograph shows an enlarged midline venous structure, with multiple arteriovenous communications leading to aneurysmal dilatation.

The vein of Galen malformation is the most common antenatally-diagnosed intracranial vascular malformation. Although named the vein of Galen malformation, the malformation is actually from an embryonic precursor- the median vein of the prosencephalon and is also known as the median prosencephalic arteriovenous fistula.

In AV shunts, blood flows directly from artery to vein, leading to an increased venous return to the heart and high-output heart failure. On examination, a typical asymmetric systolic-diastolic bruit can be auscultated over the anterior fontanel or eyeballs.

Infants and children will have less shunting and may present with hydrocephalus. Older children may have headaches and seizures and are more likely to develop intracerebral or subarachnoid hemorrhage.

Complications:

  • Worsening of the vascular steal phenomenon
  • Thrombosis of the vein of Galen
  • Rupture of the vein
  • Worsening of cardiac failure with multiorgan involvement.

Management includes early neurosurgical involvement, with embolization of the feeder vessels.

Other options:

Option B: Dandy walker syndrome- Foramen Magendie fails to open resulting in the ballooning of the posterior wall of the fourth ventricle and cyst formation in the posterior fossa

Option C: Arnold Chiari malformation- Displacement of the brainstem and cerebellum in the spinal canal 

Option D: Sturge weber syndrome- Triad of a port-wine stain, leptomeningeal angioma, and glaucoma

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about iodine-based contrast media?

choices.text: They do not interfere with the clotting times.
Iohexol is an ionic iodine-based contrast.
They are excreted unchanged via the kidneys.
They are used in magnetic resonance imaging.

questions.solution:
Iodine-based contrast media are excreted unchanged via the kidneys.

Iodine-based contrast media:

Iodine provides the radio-opacity, while the other compounds act as carriers of iodine. They are commonly used in angiography and computed tomography. They interfere with the clotting times. Hence, clotting tests are usually avoided until 6 hours after the administration of contrast media. They are excreted unchanged via the kidneys.

Iodine-based contrast media are classified as ionic and non-ionic, based on the nature of the compound to which the iodine is bound. Ionic media consists of iodine bound to inorganic compounds, while non-ionic media consists of iodine bound to an organic compound. The common examples of ionic and non-ionic iodine-based contrast media are iothalamate and iohexol, respectively.

questions.solution:
The imaging modality shown is called diffusion tensor imaging (DTI).

Diffusion tensor imaging is a variation of diffusion-weighted imaging, where the diffusion of the fluid, is assessed in six or more directions. The technique is based on the principle that the diffusion in the brain is directionally dependent (anisotropic), which is more in the compacted white matter tracts, and least evident in grey matter.

The technique is used for mapping of the white matter tracts and hence is useful in evaluating the connectivity between various brain regions, and identifying any disease process that affects it.

The image below shows diffusion tensor tractography:

Arcuate fasciculus (AF), the superior longitudinal fasciculus (SLF), the inferior longitudinal fasciculus (ILF), the uncinate fasciculus (UF), and inferior fronto-occipital fasciculus (IFOF). (Arrows at bottom right. A: Anterior, L: Lateral).

  • Option b: Dynamic susceptibility contrast MRI measures induced alterations in the transverse relaxation times (T2 and T2*). This results in signal loss causing transient darkening of the tissues.
  • Option d: Functional magnetic resonance imaging detects changes in the regional cerebral blood flow during various brain activities. It is used to study the eloquent cortical activation.

  • Hippocampal volumetry.

The investigation of choice for ischemic stroke is a diffusion-weighted MRI.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the ENT OPD with complaints of recent onset right-sided hearing loss and tinnitus. On investigation, he was found to have a mass in his brain as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis in the above case?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on clinical symptoms and MRI image is vestibular schwannoma. The MRI scan image shows a tumor arising at the cerebellopontine angle (C-P angle). 

They are commonly known as acoustic neuromas. The term vestibular schwannoma is preferred as these tumors most frequently arise from the vestibular portion of the vestibulocochlear nerve (cranial nerve VIII-CN VIII) and arise from Schwann cells. 

Vestibular schwannomas are the most common C-P angle tumors. Extracanalicular extension into the cerebellopontine angle (path of least resistance) leads to its characteristic ice-cream cone appearance. Bilateral vestibular schwannomas are highly suggestive of neurofibromatosis type 2.

Patients present with adult-onset sensorineural progressive hearing loss, with non-pulsatile tinnitus. There is no relationship between the size of the tumor and the degree of hearing loss. Other symptoms are due to the compression of trigeminal nerve(CN V), facial nerve(CN VII), Vestibulocochlear nerve(CN VIII), and cerebellum.

MRI is the imaging technique of choice. High-resolution T2-weighted imaging is the most commonly used sequence.

Option B: Craniopharyngioma is primarily a suprasellar tumor and presents most commonly with headaches.

Option C: Meningiomas are mostly supratentorial tumors with features of headache, paresis, or altered mental state.

Option D: Glomus tumor is a head and neck paraganglioma that may arise from Jacobson nerve, Arnold nerve, or the jugular bulb. Salt and pepper appearance is seen in T1 and T2 images.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements about the deterministic effects of radiation.
  1. It is associated with damage to the DNA of cells.
  2. The severity of these effects is independent of the dose received.
  3. Examples include oligospermia, skin erythema, and epilation.
  4. Below the threshold dose, harmful effects do not occur.
  5. The fetus is more vulnerable to these effects between the 2nd to 20th week of gestation
questions.solution:
Statements 3, 4, and 5 are correct about the deterministic effects of radiation.

The harmful effects of radiation may be classified into two general categories: Stochastic effects and nonstochastic/deterministic effects.

Non-stochastic/Deterministic effects: 

These effects do not occur below a threshold dose. The severity of the effect increases as the dose increases. These effects are associated with radiation-induced killing or malfunction of cells. Skin erythema, epilation, cataracts, and transient oligospermia are a few examples of nonstochastic/deterministic effects.

The fetus is most vulnerable to deterministic effects of radiation between the 2nd and 20th week of gestation. Usually, no deterministic effects occur at a dose below 100 mGy which is the threshold for most imaging modalities.

Stochastic effects: 

Stochastic effects of ionizing radiation are chance events associated with damage to the DNA of cells. They may result in cancer or heritable effects. The incidence of these effects is directly proportionate to the dose of radiation in organs or tissues, but the severity of the effect is independent of the dose received. (All or none phenomenon)

questions.text:
A 50-year-old woman presents with episodes of intermittent right upper abdominal pain for the past few months. She underwent cholecystectomy a year back. Investigations showed elevated AST and ALT levels and imaging revealed a dilated common bile duct with prolonged biliary drainage time. What is the gold standard for diagnosing this condition?

AST - Aspartate aminotransferase
ALT - Alanine aminotransferase
HIDA - Hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid
ERCP - Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of a Sphincter of Oddi dysfunction. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) with manometry of the biliary and pancreatic sphincters is the gold standard for its diagnosis.

Sphincter of Oddi dyskinesia or dysfunction (SOD) is characterized by abdominal pain, biliary or pancreatic duct dilatation due to abnormal function of the sphincter of Oddi.

Clinical types include biliary and pancreatic SOD.

Biliary type presents with biliary pain, raised liver enzymes, and/or dilation of the bile duct and/or evidence of delayed emptying on biliary imaging. It should be excluded in patients with post-cholecystectomy syndrome. Pancreatic SOD presents as recurrent episodes of unexplained acute pancreatitis.

CT and magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) can demonstrate dilatation of the biliary and pancreatic ducts. MRCP with intravenous secretin injection demonstrates dilatation of the pancreatic duct due to increased sphincter pressures. Endoscopic ultrasound can also be used. HIDA scan will show delayed biliary transit.

The gold standard investigation is ERCP with manometry and is indicated in disabling pain, when noninvasive investigations fail to demonstrate structural abnormalities and when conservative therapy fails. Basal sphincter pressure higher than 40 mm Hg is suggestive of SOD.

ERCP stands for Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangio Pancreaticography. It involves the use of a side-viewing endoscope which is passed through the pylorus of the stomach into the second part of the duodenum to visualize the papilla.

It can be a therapeutic and diagnostic modality specifically for viewing the distal biliary tree. The most common indication for therapeutic ERCP is the relief of biliary obstruction due to gallstone disease and benign or malignant biliary strictures.  

Related Pearl: Diagnostic Evaluation of the Bile Ducts

Diagnostic Evaluation of the Bile Ducts

  • Hepatobiliary ultrasound: Initial procedure of choice in investigating possible biliary tract obstruction
  • CT scan: Procedure of choice in investigating possible biliary obstruction if diagnostic limitations prevent HBUS
  • MRCP: Useful modality for visualizing pancreatic and biliary ducts
  • ERCP: Best visualisation of distal biliary tract
    • Endoscopic sphincterotomy and stone removal can also be done
  • PTC(Percutaneous Transhepatic Cholangiography): Best visualisation of proximal biliary tract
    • Indicated when ERCP is contraindicated or failed
  • EUS: Most sensitive method to detect ampullary stones

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the emergency room with a history of recurrent episodes of bloody stool. The following investigation is performed, and the child was found to have Meckel diverticulum. Which of the following radionuclide agents is used for this investigation?
questions.solution:
The given image is that of  99mTc-pertechnetate scintigraphy, which is the most accurate diagnostic test for Meckel's diverticulum in children.

Meckel's diverticulum results from the failure of the yolk sac to close during fetal life. It is located on the anti-mesenteric border of the ileum. It is usually detected incidentally but can present with gastrointestinal bleeding. The bleeding is usually from a chronic acid-induced ulcer adjacent to a Meckel diverticulum that contains ectopic gastric mucosa.

Radionuclide like the 99mTc-pertechnetate is preferentially taken up by the mucus-secreting cells of gastric mucosa and ectopic gastric tissue in the diverticulum.

 Other uses of 99mTc-pertechnetate:

  • Thyroid imaging
  • Parathyroid imaging to distinguish it from the thyroid gland
  • Testicular imaging

questions.text: A newborn is brought with severe respiratory distress soon after birth. A chest X-ray was done and is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario and the X-ray showing herniation of the bowel loops into the chest is suggestive of congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH).

CDH is a structural diaphragmatic defect with or without abdominal contents in the thorax. It allows the abdominal organs to push into the chest cavity resulting in pulmonary hypoplasia and pulmonary hypertension. The most common type of CDH is a bochdalek hernia involving the left side. They may also have a scaphoid abdomen.

Babies with CDH present with respiratory distress immediately after birth characterized by tachypnea, grunting, use of accessory muscles, and cyanosis. Auscultation of the chest may reveal bowel sounds with reduced breath sounds.

Diagnosis is done by a chest radiograph showing herniated bowel loops hemithorax, displacement of the mediastinum to the contralateral side, and reduced lung space. Prenatal diagnosis can be made using ultrasonography between 16 to 24 weeks of gestation.

The immediate step in the management is to place a naso- or orogastric tube for decompression. The airway is to be secured with endotracheal intubation. Bag and mask ventilation should be avoided. Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) and high-frequency oscillatory ventilation have been used as a part of the ventilation strategy.

Bag and mask ventilation should be avoided. Surgical repair of the defect is to be considered at least 48 hours after stabilization and resolution of pulmonary hypertension.

Related Pearl: Radiologic features of the major respiratory distress disorders in newborns

Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia

  • Mediastinal shift
  • Bowel loops in the left hemithorax

 

Respiratory Distress Syndrome

  • Low lung volume
  • Symmetric ground-glass opacity (reticulogranular pattern)
  • Air bronchogram
  • White-out lung (severe disease)

Chest radiograph (A) on Day 2: shows reticulogranular opacities throughout both lungs with prominent air bronchograms. The cardiac silhouette is preserved and both lungs are hypoaerated.

Chest radiograph (B) on Day 9 (untreated): shows more severe changes. There is obliteration of the cardiac and diaphragmatic contours due to marked opacification, giving a complete ‘white out’ appearance

 Meconium Aspiration Syndrome

  • Hyperinflation
  • Patchy infiltrates
  • Coarse streaking

Related Pearl: Congenital diaphragmatic hernias (CDH)

It is due to the failure of the closure of the pleuroperitoneal canal in the developing fetus (Normally the pleuroperitoneal cavities separate by 8-10 weeks of gestation). Left-sided hernias are more common(80%).

The two well-recognized congenital sites where abdominal viscera can herniate into the chest are:

  • The foramen of Morgagni: a hernia in the anteromedial part of the diaphragm with a defect between the sternal and costal attachments. The most commonly involved viscus is the transverse colon.
  • The foramen of Bochdalek: through the dome of the diaphragm posterolaterally

CDH causes pulmonary hypoplasia (bilateral) by compressing the developing lung. These lungs have smaller bronchi, with less bronchial branching and less alveolar surface area than lungs in normal infants. Pulmonary hypertension may also develop due to increased thickness of arteriolar smooth muscle and also by multiple local and systemic vasoactive factors.

Clinical features:

  • respiratory distress at birth
  • grunting respiration
  • chest retractions
  • dyspnea
  • cyanosis
  • scaphoid abdomen
  • decreased breath sounds along with bowel sound over the chest with CDH
  • shifting of heart sounds to the right (for left-sided CDH)

questions.text: The plain X-ray of the erect abdomen of a 30-year-old male, who came with complaints of acute abdominal pain and distension is shown in the below image. All of the following radiological signs can be seen in the given condition except:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and x-ray images are suggestive of pneumoperitoneum. All the given signs are seen in this except spinnaker-sail sign.

The spinnaker sign (also known as the angel wing sign) is a sign of pneumomediastinum seen on neonatal chest radiographs. It refers to the thymus being outlined by air with each lobe displaced laterally and appearing like spinnaker sails.

Pneumoperitoneum refers to air within the peritoneal cavity. Rigler's sign, telltale triangle sign, falciform ligament sign are the radiological findings seen in supine abdominal x-ray.

The supine abdominal radiograph of the patient showing the presence of air in the bilateral subphrenic spaces and a linear density on the ventral surface of the liver (arrow), known as the falciform ligament sign.

questions.text: A 2-week-old girl born at 35 weeks of gestation presents with lethargy and bilious vomiting for the past one day. She has diffuse abdominal distension and a sunken anterior fontanelle. Bowel movements were normal prior to this but she now has bloody stool. Her plain abdominal X-ray is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a premature infant presenting with lethargy, bilious vomiting, diffuse abdominal distension, dehydration, and bloody stool with an X-ray showing gas in the bowel wall is likely to have necrotizing enterocolitis.

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) is a rapidly progressing disease causing extensive bowel necrosis, infection, and perforation in newborns. Premature, low-birth-weight (LBW) infants are at an increased risk for developing this life-threatening emergency. 

Pathogenesis of this condition involves mucosal ischemia that progresses to necrosis. Subsequently, there is gaseous accumulation in the bowel submucosa termed as pneumatosis intestinalis that can be further complicated by perforation, peritonitis, sepsis, and eventual death. 

Patients have feeding intolerance, vomiting, and associated dehydration (sunken fontanelle), abdominal distension, occult/gross blood in stool, and temperature instability.

Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall). Gas may be sometimes visualized in the portal venous tree. NE cases complicated by perforation may show pneumoperitoneum (gas under diaphragm) on abdominal x-ray. 

Other options:

Option A- A duodenal atresia is a form of intestinal atresia that presents with symptoms of gastric outlet obstruction, bilious vomiting, and dehydration. Abdominal x-ray findings show a classic double-bubble sign due to duodenal and gastric distension with no air distal to the point of obstruction. 

Option B- Cystic fibrosis (CF) is associated with meconium ileus, wherein the meconium becomes impacted in the distal small bowel. There is a failure to pass meconium in the first 24 hours after birth. CF patients also present with abdominal distension and bilious emesis but abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

The below image shows a contrast enema image demonstrating a microcolon. 

Option D- Intussusception is characterized by the invagination of a proximal bowel segment (usually, the ileum) into the segment distal to it (ascending colon). It is commonly seen in children between the age of 6 to 9 months and presents with colicky abdominal pain and passage of red-currant-jelly stool. Barium enema findings include a classic claw sign or coiled spring sign that represents the telescoping intestinal segment. Ultrasound imaging demonstrates the target sign which shows the telescoping segment surrounded by the lumen of the adjacent intestinal segment. It is shown in the image below.

questions.text: A patient underwent an imaging study; the findings are shown in the image given below. Which of the following compounds is used for this investigation?
questions.solution:
The image shows a positron-emission tomography (PET) scan. PET involves the use of a radiolabeled bio-compound such as 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is injected intravenously. This compound is taken up and broken down in the cells.

It is based on the principle that tumor cells have a high metabolic rate and can metabolize FDG. However, tumor cells can metabolize FDG only to FDG-6-phosphate, and no further. Hence, it accumulates in tumor cells and can be detected and quantified.

Applications of PET:

  • Oncologic:
    • Detection, staging, drug response
    • Differentiation between radiation necrosis and recurrence
  • Neurologic:
    • Early diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease
    • Localization of seizure focus in the interictal phase
    • Localizing eloquent areas (e.g. speech, motor function)
  • Cardiac:
    • Identification of hibernating myocardium

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient who is on oral contraceptive pills presents with fever, headache, and double vision. On doing a contrast-enhanced CT scan, the following image was seen. Identify the sign seen in this image.
questions.solution:
The empty delta sign is seen in the given image. The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cerebral venous thrombosis.

In this patient, cerebral venous thrombosis is most likely to have occurred due to oral contraceptive pills. Cerebral infection, local trauma, dehydration, pregnancy, smoking, and vasculitis are some other common reasons for cerebral venous thrombosis.

The 'empty delta' sign is a CT sign of dural venous sinus thrombosis of the superior sagittal sinus, where the thrombus becomes less dense and the contrast outlines a triangular filling defect (clot) within the sinus lumen. It is only described with contrast-enhanced CT-scan or MRI, not with non-contrast CT(NCCT) or non-contrast MRI.

On doing an NCCT scan, an acutely thrombosed sinus appears hyperdense and expanded. This is called the 'delta sign'. It also gives a cordlike hyper-attenuation within a dural venous sinus giving the 'cord sign' of cerebral venous thrombosis.

Other options: 

Option B: Pseudo-delta sign is a hyperdense extra-axial triangular image surrounding the low density of superior sagittal sinus on an NCCT scan. This is seen in subarachnoid hemorrhage. 

Option D: Double delta sign is seen on an MRI in a bucket-handle meniscal tear when the inner meniscal fragment is flipped anteriorly adjacent to the anterior horn of the donor site.

questions.text:
Match the following antenatal USG findings and the associated conditions:
USG finding Associated condition
1) Banana sign a) Intrauterine death
2) Spalding sign b) Spina bifida
3) Frog-eye sign c) Normal gestation
4) Double decidual sac sign d) Anencephaly
questions.solution:
The correct option is 1-b,2-a,3-d,4-c

Banana sign - Spina bifida

Spalding sign - Intrauterine death

Frog-eye sign - Anencephaly

Double decidual sac sign - Normal gestation

Banana sign - Anterior curvature of cerebellum along with effacement of cisterna magna produces this appearance. Seen in spina bifida associated with Arnold-Chiari malformation.

Frog eye or Mickey Mouse appearance: It is seen in Anencephaly, which is the absence of cranial bones with exposed rudimentary brain tissue. This finding is when seen in the coronal plane due to absent cranial bone/brain and bulging orbits.

Spalding sign - It is a sign of intrauterine death. It is the irregular overlapping of the skull bones on one another. It is due to the liquefaction of brain matter and softening of ligamentous structures supporting the skull. Usually seen 7 days after death.

Double decidual sac sign: Normal Ultrasonographic appearance of an intrauterine gestational sac. Seen as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presented with pain, swelling, and redness in his right leg for the past 2 weeks. On examination, purulent discharge was observed exuding from the proximal end of the right tibia. There is no history of any chronic illness or trauma. What is the radiological investigation of choice for the early stage of this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with symptoms of pain, swelling, and redness of the lower limb which was later associated with the development of a discharging sinus is suffering from osteomyelitis. MRI is the investigation of choice for the diagnosis of osteomyelitis. 

The characteristic early signs of osteomyelitis include bone marrow edema. This is seen as a low T1 signal in the bone marrow, along with a high signal on T2 MRI.

Abscesses are the walled pockets of infection serving as complications in both the early and late stages of osteomyelitis. They appear as well-demarcated low-signal collections on T1 and high signal collections similar to fluid on T2 images. Usual locations include the bone itself, adjacent soft tissue, and subperiosteal spaces.

X-rays are not useful in early acute osteomyelitis because of minimal findings. Exposure to ionizing radiation and limited soft-tissue contrast is the main disadvantage of CT that makes it less useful. 

Osteomyelitis is an acute or chronic inflammatory process involving the bone and its structures secondary to infection with pyogenic organisms, including bacteria, fungi, and mycobacteria. The bone becomes susceptible to disease due to large inoculation of microorganisms, from trauma, ischemia, or the presence of foreign bodies because bone sites to which microorganisms can bind are exposed.

The bone can get infected by a hematogenous route through bacteremia seeding of a bone infection from a distant source of infection, contiguous spread from surrounding tissue and joints, or direct inoculation of bone from trauma or surgery. The most common pathogen of acute and chronic hematogenous osteomyelitis in adults and children is Staphylococcus aureus. Other common pathogens are:

  • Coagulase-negative staphylococcus
  • Beta-hemolytic streptococcus
  • Enterococci
  • Aerobic gram-negative bacilli (including pseudomonas species, Enterobacter species, Escherichia coli)
  • Anaerobic gram-negative bacilli (such as peptostreptococcus, Clostridium species, Bacteroides)

Osteomyelitis can be classified as acute or chronic based on histopathological findings rather than the duration of illness. Infection occurring before the development of sequestra is referred to as acute osteomyelitis. It usually takes place within two weeks of disease onset. The infection is considered chronic following the development of necrotic bone and the formation of sequestra. Acute infections generally present with pain, swelling, and redness of the affected area associated with systemic illness while discharging sinuses may be present in chronic infections.

Surgical debridement of all diseased bone is required as antibiotics penetrate poorly into infected fluid collections such as abscesses and injured or necrotic bone. Thus, the removal of necrotic tissue and bone is usually indicated where feasible. The cornerstone of treatment for osteomyelitis is prolonged antibiotic therapy.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis of the computed tomography (CT) image provided below?
questions.solution:
The given image is a CT pulmonary angiography showing a pulmonary (saddle) embolism.

CT pulmonary angiography using multi-detector CT is the best investigation for pulmonary embolism. 

An embolus in the bifurcation of the main pulmonary artery is referred to as a saddle embolus. Pulmonary emboli (PE) originate from deep venous thromboses. Fragmented thrombi from DVTs are carried through progressively larger veins and the right side of the heart, before slamming into the pulmonary arterial vasculature.

Depending on the size of the embolus, it can occlude the main pulmonary artery; straddle the pulmonary artery bifurcation (saddle embolus); or pass out into the smaller, branching arteries.

The below image shows a CT thorax of saddle embolism.

Other options

Option A- Pulmonary hypertension (PH) is defined as an increase in vascular resistance of the pulmonary circulation involving a combination of vasoconstriction and remodeling of small vessels. Hemodynamically, it is defined as a systolic pulmonary artery pressure of more than 35 mmHg or a mean pulmonary artery pressure (mPAP) >20 mmHg

A diameter of the main pulmonary artery at the level of its bifurcation of more than 29 mm helps in the diagnosis of PH.

Option B- Thoracic aortic aneurysm occurs due to the intrinsic weakness of the aortic wall and they rarely manifest with symptoms. A CECT scan is the most widely used for diagnosis and it assesses the size, extent, and location of the aneurysm.

The below image shows a CT scan of a ruptured thoracic aortic aneurysm. The black arrow is the aorta and the white arrow is blood in the thorax.

Option D- The mural thrombus of the aorta is the thrombus attached to the wall of an aorta. They occur in the normal or minimally atherosclerotic vessel. The modality for diagnosis of mural thrombi is CT or MRI angiography.

Related Pearl: Chest X Ray signs in pulmonary embolism

Westermark's sign: Focal area of oligemia (decreased vascular markings) distal to the embolism.

Hampton's hump: Peripherally placed wedge-shaped or dome-shaped opacity due to infarction of lung tissue.

Palla's sign: Increased size of the right descending pulmonary artery with a sausage-like appearance.

Fleishner sign: enlarged pulmonary artery.

Melting sign: an infarct shows rapid clearing in contrast to pneumonic consolidation.

McConnell's sign (indirect sign of PE seen in transthoracic echo): hypokinesis of the right ventricular free wall with normal motion of the right ventricle apex.

Knuckle or sausage’ sign: dilatation of the pulmonary artery, proximal to the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.  

Note - A normal chest X-ray does not rule out pulmonary embolism in a patient with unexplained acute tachypnea or hypoxemia.

Pulmonary embolism rule out criteria (PERC):

This is a quick OPD/casualty tool to rule out pulmonary embolism in patients with low clinical probability. It comprises eight clinical variables. If the patient meets all eight criteria, there is no need for further investigations. The variables include: 

  1. Age <50 years
  2. Heart rate <100 bpm
  3. SpO2 ≥95%
  4. No unilateral leg swelling
  5. No hemoptysis
  6. No recent trauma or surgery
  7. No history of venous thromboembolism
  8. No use of hormonal therapy.

questions.text: Gallium scan finding shown below is seen in _________
questions.solution:
The given Gallium scan shows the Panda sign which is seen in sarcoidosis.

It is a gallium-67 citrate scan finding. It is due to the bilateral involvement of parotid and lacrimal glands in sarcoidosis, superimposed on the normal uptake in the nasopharyngeal mucosa.

Other signs seen in Sarcoidosis are:

The lambda sign is seen on gallium-67 scans in the setting of thoracic sarcoidosis. Bilateral hilar and right paratracheal lymph nodes are typically involved which can resemble the lambda symbol (λ).

Garland triad, also known as the 1-2-3 sign or Pawnbrokers sign, is a lymph node enlargement pattern which has been described in sarcoidosis:

  • Right paratracheal nodes
  • Right hilar nodes
  • Left hilar nodes

Galaxy sign, initially described as the sarcoid galaxy, represents a coalescent granuloma seen in a minority of patients with pulmonary sarcoidosis.

questions.text: A woman came with complaints of breast pain following surgery. Her MRI is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows curvilinear hypointense lines (arrows) in the left breast implant indicative of the collapsed shell floating in the silicone gel. This is called the linguini sign that is seen in intra-capsular rupture of a breast implant.

After implantation of a silicone or saline breast implant, a fibrous capsule (scar) forms around the implant shell. In an intracapsular rupture, the contents of the implant are contained by the fibrous scar, while the shell appears as a group of wavy lines.

Multiple hyperintense foci on T2-weighted images are sometimes found within the implant lumen. These findings are referred to as the salad oil sign or droplet sign.

Indications for breast MRI:

  • Screening for DCIS in high-risk patients
  • Evaluation of breast implants
  • Evaluation of breast scar tissue versus recurrent tumors.

Ultrasound is the preferred modality of imaging in suspected cases of extracapsular rupture. The snowstorm sign on USG is seen in extracapsular rupture.

questions.text: Which of the following is the imaging modality of choice for diagnosing primary hyperparathyroidism?
questions.solution:
Sestamibi scan is the imaging of choice for diagnosing primary hyperparathyroidism.

Sestamibi is a monovalent lipophilic cation. It shows passive diffusion across cell membranes and accumulates in mitochondria. Because of its accumulation in the mitochondria, there is a difference in the rate at which it gets washed out depending on the number of mitochondria in each tissue. 

In parathyroid adenomas, there is a high concentration of oxyphilic cells with high mitochondrial content.

The three protocols for sestamibi scanning:

  • Single-isotope dual-phase scan
  • Dual-isotope subtraction imaging
  • Single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT)

SPECT is commonly used because of its improved spatial resolution. Sestamibi combined with CT can be used to detect smaller parathyroid tissues. It can also detect ectopic glands in the mediastinum or in the deeper cervical region.

Other imaging modalities for parathyroid localization:

  • Ultrasonography:
    • It is inexpensive and noninvasive.
    • Mediastinal parathyroid tissue cannot be detected because USG cannot penetrate the sternum or clavicles.
  • Four-dimensional CT: 
    • It has a very high sensitivity. 
    • Increased radiation exposure and use of contrast are potential disadvantages.
  • Selective venous sampling for PTH:
    • It can be used for the exact localization of adenomas.

questions.text: An infant was brought to the emergency with an incessant cry, abdominal distension, and passing blood-stained stools.  A donut-shaped mass was visualized in the right hypochondrium on ultrasonography. On performing barium studies, which sign would be consistent with the diagnosis of this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of an infant with incessant crying, abdominal distension, and blood-stained stools with a doughnut sign on ultrasonography is suggestive of intussusception. On performing barium studies, coiled spring appearance is consistent with the diagnosis of this condition. 

Intussusception occurs when a portion of the alimentary tract is telescoped into an adjacent segment. The most common location of intussusception is ileocolic. 

Causes of intussusception are:

  • Idiopathic - most common cause in children
  • Pathological lead points such as enlarged submucosal Peyer's patch, lymphoma, intestinal polyp, leiomyomas, etc.
  • Meckel's diverticulum
  • A recent upper GI or respiratory infection, rotavirus vaccination has also shown some association with intussusception in children.

The characteristic clinical triad includes:

  • Pain
  • Palpable sausage-shaped mass
  • Red currant jelly stools

USG findings in intussusception include:

  • Target sign/ doughnut sign/ bull's eye sign - This is seen in axial view/transverse plane on ultrasonography. The appearance is generated by concentric alternating echogenic (mucosa and muscularis) with hypoechogenic bands (submucosa).
  • Pseudo kidney sign: this is seen in the longitudinal section of the bowel:
    • Edematous bowel resembles renal parenchyma 
    • Mesentery which is dragged into the intussusception resembles renal hilum.
  • Crescent in a doughnut sign.

Barium contrast shows a coiled spring appearance with barium in the lumen of the intussusceptum and in the intraluminal space. Plain radiograph may show a meniscus sign i.e. soft tissue mass contrasting the bowel that is air-filled. 

Treatment: Reduction of intussusception should be done immediately after the diagnosis. Radiologic hydrostatic reduction has a high success rate in ileocolic intussusception. Surgical reduction is only done in the presence of refractory shock, suspected bowel necrosis or perforation, peritonitis, and multiple recurrences.

Other options:

Options A and D: Pseudo kidney sign and target sign are ultrasonographic findings of instussuception. 

The ultrasonography image below shows pseudo kidney sign and target sign:

 

Option B: The corkscrew pattern is pathognomic of midgut volvulus on upper GI studies. It represents the duodenum and jejunum spiralling around the mesenteric vessels.

questions.text: A child presented with a history of a road traffic accident. The finding in the axial CT image is as shown below. It is most commonly caused due to bleeding from _________
questions.solution:
The given CT image shows the typical bi-convex hyperdense lesion not crossing cranial sutures, characteristic of an extradural hemorrhage. It is most commonly due to bleeding from the middle meningeal artery.

As the dura mater tends to adhere to the skull, the hematoma collecting between the skull and this dura is seen on CT sections as a biconvex dense area immediately beneath the skull vault, convex towards both the brain and the vault. They tend not to cross the suture lines.

The thin squamous temporal bone is the common site of injury. The hematoma usually lies beneath a fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone. The underlying brain is displaced but often appears intrinsically normal.

Note:

The pterion is an H-shaped sutural junction between four bones of the skull:

  • Frontal bone
  • Parietal bone
  • Greater wing of the sphenoid bone
  • Squamous part of the temporal bone

The pterion is an important landmark because it overlies the anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery and lateral fissure of the cerebral hemisphere.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: A child with progressive cyanosis was brought to the hospital. The chest radiograph of the patient is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a cyanotic heart disease and the chest X-ray shows a box-shaped heart with oligemic lung fields. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is Ebstein’s anomaly.

Ebstein's anomaly is a congenital anomaly of the tricuspid valve wherein there is downward displacement of the abnormal tricuspid valve into the right ventricle. This leads to tricuspid regurgitation and atrialization of the right ventricle.

It is usually associated with an atrial septal defect. In severe cases, there is right-to-left shunting at the atrial level with subsequent cyanosis. In newborns marked cyanosis, massive cardiomegaly and holosystolic murmurs are seen. 

On the chest radiograph, Ebstein’s anomaly leads to a grossly enlarged cardiac contour and a prominent curved right atrial border, appearing as a box-shaped enlargement of the heart. In newborns with severe disease, the pulmonary fields may be totally obscured. Echocardiography is diagnostic. It provides the degree of tricuspid valve displacement, dilatation of the right atrium, and any right ventricular obstruction if present.

Other options: 

Option B: Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection (TAPV) presents with severe cyanosis and respiratory distress. The radiograph shows a snowman appearance or figure of 8 configurations of heart.

Option C: Transposition of great arteries (TGA) can present from birth to infancy with cyanosis, decreased exercise tolerance, and poor physical development. Radiography shows the egg-on-string appearance of the heart. 

Option D: Tricuspid atresia also presents also with cyanosis at birth and holosystolic murmur along the left border of the sternum. Cyanosis with left axis deviation on ECG is suggestive of tricuspid atresia. 2D Echo shows a fibromuscular membrane in place of the tricuspid valve, small right ventricle, an enlarged left ventricle, and a VSD.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with chest pain and breathlessness which is more on lying down and relieved on sitting upright. On examination, heart sounds are muffled. His chest X-ray is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and X-ray appearance of the money bag heart is suggestive of pericardial effusion.

Plain PA chest X-ray shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette. There is effacement of the normal cardiac borders, development of a flask or water bottle cardiac configuration, and bilateral hilar overlay which are features of pericardial effusion. It is also known as money bag or leather bottle-shaped heart.

Pericardial effusions occur when excess fluid collects in the pericardial space (a normal pericardial sac contains approximately 15-50 mL of fluid).

Investigation of choice: Echocardiography.

Signs on plain radiograph include:

  • Globular enlargement of the cardiac shadow giving a water bottle configuration.
  • Lateral CXR may show a vertical opaque line (pericardial fluid) separating a vertical lucent line directly behind the sternum (paracardial fat) anteriorly from a similar lucent vertical lucent line (epicardial fat) posteriorly; this is known as the Oreo cookie sign.

questions.text: The image given below is a characteristic finding of:
questions.solution:
The image shows a teardrop bladder (pear-shaped bladder) characteristically seen in pelvic hematoma. It is also seen in pelvic lipomatosis,  pelvic abscess, bilateral pelvic lymphadenopathy, and intraperitoneal bladder rupture.

A pear-shaped (or teardrop-shaped) bladder is one whose normal round or ovoid shape has been extrinsically compressed to resemble a pear. The pear may be inverted or upright, depending on how the excess pelvic tissue compresses the bladder.

Other important radiological appearances in urogenital system:

  • Fir tree/pine tree/Christmas tree bladder: Neurogenic bladder
  • Sun-burst appearance of the bladder: Extraperitoneal bladder rupture.
  • Thimble bladder: Tubercular cystitis
  • Paint-brush appearance: Medullary sponge kidney
  • Drooping flower appearance: Ectopic ureter
  • Rim sign/crescent sign: Hydronephrosis
  • Bilateral spider leg deformity: Polycystic kidney disease.
  • Flower vase curves of the ureter: Horseshoe kidney.
  • Saw-toothed or cock screw appearance of ureter: Tubercular ureteritis

questions.text:
A 46-year-old male patient presented with acute renal failure. A dynamic radionuclide renography was ordered to assess the renal perfusion. Which of the following radionuclides are preferred?

99mTc-MAG3 - mercaptoacetyltriglycine 

99m-Tc-MDP - methylene diphosphonate
questions.solution:
99mTc-MAG3 (mercaptoacetyltriglycine) is used for performing dynamic radionuclide renography, to assess renal perfusion.

99mTc-MAG3 dynamic radionuclide renography is the simplest and safest way to assess renal perfusion in patients with renal failure. It helps in differentiating the reversible causes of acute renal failure such as acute tubular necrosis, from conditions like intrinsic parenchymal disease where it is severely impaired or absent.

Dynamic renography:

  • Used to assess split renal function and drainage from the renal collecting systems in suspected obstruction
  • 99mTc-MAG3 is the most commonly used isotope in dynamic renography. Its uptake reflects the tubular function
  • 99mTc-DTPA may also be used. Its uptake reflects the glomerular function and hence, it is commonly used to assess GFR

Indications for 99mTc-MAG3 Dynamic Renography:

  • To find divided renal function and urinary drainage where the collecting system is significantly dilated
  • To find differential renal function following surgery or procedure. Examples: post pyeloplasty or post removal of a double J stent
  • To assess for a urinary leak or possible obstruction following renal transplantation

Other options:

Option A- 99mTc-pertechnetate is used in the imaging of the thyroid, salivary glands, and Meckel's diverticulum imaging.

Option B- 99mTc-sulphur colloid is used in liver/spleen imaging, and prosthetic infection.

Option D- 99m-Tc-MDP (methylene diphosphonate) is used for bone scintigraphy.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presented with headache for the past 4 months, she was treated with radiotherapy for vestibular schwannoma 2 year back. What is the probable diagnosis we can arrive from the contrast MRI shown below?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis of the above patient is meningioma.

The well-defined, hyper intense and homogeneously enhanced mass close to the midline, situated extra-axially (i.e., outside the brain parenchyma). Being non-glial in origin they arise from the meningocytes or arachnoid cap cells of the meninges, and thus can occur anywhere meninges are found.

Meningomas are associated with:

  • Female predominance (some meningiomas contain estrogen and progesterone receptors).
  • Genetic preponderance: Genetic mutations associated with meningioma are NF-2 and MEN1 mutations.
  • Ionizing radiation

Useful descriptive signs on MRI are:

  • CSF vascular cleft sign helps to establish that mass to be extra-axial. There is a cleft between tumor and normal brain parenchyma.
  • Dural tail sign: Refers to the linear extension of enhancement the dura, beyond the segment on which the tumor is based.
  • Sunburst or spoke wheel appearance of the vessels.

questions.text: A child presents with features of parkinsonism and spasticity. His MRI brain is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with the MRI image showing the eye of the tiger sign, is suggestive of the Hallervorden-Spatz syndrome.

The eye of the tiger sign refers to an abnormal, low T2 signal intensity on MRI (due to abnormal accumulation of iron) in the globus pallidus, with a longitudinal stripe of high signal intensity (due to gliosis and spongiosis).

Hallervorden-Spatz syndrome, or pantothenate kinase-associated neurodegeneration (PKAN), is an autosomal recessive disorder. It causes involuntary spasticity and progressive dementia, along with parkinsonism and dystonia starting from childhood itself. It is a subset of neurodegeneration with brain iron accumulation (NBIA). 

The image below shows an MRI depicting the eye of a tiger sign.

questions.text:
A woman presents to you with a feeling of heaviness of her head, swelling on the forehead, and dull headache throughout the day. On investigating further, her serum ALP levels are raised and the following radiographic changes are seen. What is the likely diagnosis?

ALP- Alkaline phosphatase
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of heaviness of head, swelling on the forehead, dull headache throughout the day, raised serum ALP levels, and the radiograph showing Tam o' Shanter sign are suggestive of Paget's disease.

Paget's bone disease (PBD) is a chronic disease of increased bone turnover in localized areas resulting in enlarged and thickened bones. There is a significant increase in osteoclastic and osteoblastic activity. It is usually asymptomatic but can present with a dull aching pain unless the disease is severe. Bowing of leg bones may occur. There is an increased risk of pathological fractures and osteosarcoma. Serum ALP levels may be raised or maybe normal. Treatment is done using intravenous zoledronate given as a single infusion of 4-5 mg.

Radiographic features: 

  • The early phase features the osteolytic (lucent) region which is later followed by coarse trabeculae and bony enlargement.
  • Sclerotic changes occur much later in the disease process. 
  • Osteoporosis circumscripta is seen as a large, well-defined lytic lesion
  • Cotton wool appearance  is seen as a mixed lytic and sclerotic lesion of the skull
  • Tam o'Shanter sign is frontal bone enlargement, with the appearance of the skull falling over the facial bones.
  • Flame-shaped lesions- Seen in long bones due to localized osteolysis/osteopenia.

Other options:

Option B: Hyperparathyroidism is characterised by increased circulating parathyroid hormone levels. There is osteoclastic hyperactivity resulting in hypercalcemia, hypercalciuria, nephrocalcinosis and chondrocalcinosis. Typical features in radiology include subperiosteal cortical resorption and osteoporosis. 

Option C: Multiple myeloma is the most common primary malignancy occurring in the bone and is characterised by the presence of punched-out osteolytic lesions resulting in a pepper pot appearance of the axial skeleton.

Option D: Osteomyelitis refers to the infection of the bone more commonly starting in the trabeculae. Radiographic features include periosteal new bone formation around the second week of infection which later progresses to periosteal thickening.

questions.text: A young man presented with chronic cough and evening rise in body temperature. He has a history of decreased appetite and weight loss. On examination, a mass is found in the right iliac fossa. A barium meal follow-through image of the patient is given below. Which of the following radiological findings is not seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the barium meal follow-through study showing conical caecum, narrowing of the terminal ileum, and proximal ileal dilation are suggestive of ileocaecal tuberculosis. The radiological finding not seen in ileocecal tuberculosis is the apple-core sign. Apple-core or napkin-ring sign is typically seen in carcinoma colon as seen in the image below. It appears as short irregular stenosis with sharp shoulders at either end (yellow arrows).

 

Intestinal tuberculosis is an infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Patients typically present with cough, evening rise in temperature, weight loss, malaise, abdominal pain with distension, and intermittent diarrhea. On palpation, the abdomen feels doughy and a mass may be palpated in the right iliac fossa. The ileocaecal junction is the most common site of tuberculosis in the gastrointestinal tract. Other sites involved in the abdomen are the proximal colon and peritoneum.

Barium meal follow-through study findings in ileocaecal tuberculosis include:

  • Fleischner sign- narrow ileum with the thickened ileocecal valve
  • The ileocaecal angle becomes obtuse
  • Caecum appears pulled up and hepatic flexure is pulled down
  • Contracted conical caecum
  • Gooseneck deformity - due to contracted, and pulled-up cecum as well as straightening of the terminal ileum
  • String sign - due to persistently narrowed intestinal segment due to inflammation

  • Yellow arrow- shrunken conical caecum
  • Red arrow- strictures narrowing of the terminal ileum and ileocaecal junction
  • Blue arrow- proximal ileal dilation

  • Earliest feature is spasm and hypermotility, with edema of the valve.
  • Thickening of the valve lips, with narrowing of the terminal ileum: Fleischner or inverted umbrella sign is characteristic of TB.
  • In advance disease, the characteristic deformity includes symmetric, annular, napkin-ring stenosis and obstruction or shortening and pouch formation.
  • The cecum is shrunken and retracts out of the iliac fossa due to contraction of the mesocolon: Pulled-up cecum
  • Loss of ileocecal angle with dilated terminal ileum: Gooseneck deformity
  • Narrowing of the terminal ileum due to irritability, along with shortened rigid cecum: Sterlein sign
  • Persistent narrow stream of barium in the bowel indicates stenosis: String sign
